sn17.3:1.3: Once upon a time in a certain lake there was a large family of turtles that had lived there for a long time.
sn17.3:1.4: Then one of the turtles said to another,
sn17.3:1.5: ‘My dear turtle, don’t you go to that place.’
sn17.3:1.6: But that turtle did go to that place,
sn17.3:1.7: and a hunter pierced her with a harpoon.
sn17.3:1.8: Then that turtle went back to the other turtle.
sn17.3:1.9: When the other turtle saw her coming off in the distance,
sn17.3:1.11: ‘My dear turtle, I hope you didn’t go to that place!’
sn17.3:1.13: ‘But my dear turtle, I hope you’re not hurt or injured!’
sn17.3:1.14: ‘I’m not hurt or injured. But this cord keeps dragging behind me.’
sn17.3:1.15: ‘Indeed, my dear turtle, you’re hurt and injured!
sn17.3:1.16: Your father and grandfather met with tragedy and disaster because of such a cord.
sn17.3:1.17: Go now, you are no longer one of us.’
sn17.3:2.1: ‘Hunter’ is a term for Māra the Wicked.
sn17.3:2.2: ‘Harpoon’ is a term for possessions, honor, and popularity.
sn17.3:2.3: ‘Cord’ is a term for greed and relishing.
sn17.3:2.4: Whoever enjoys and likes arisen possessions, honor, and popularity is called a mendicant who has been pierced with a harpoon. They’ve met with tragedy and disaster, and the Wicked One can do with them what he wants.
sn17.3:2.6: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity. …”
